S. Korean police crackdown protested
    Pyongyang, April 21 (KCNA) -- Seven South Korean public and religious organizations including the "Korean Confederation of Trade Unions" (KCTU) and the citizens' solidarity for democratic society on April 17 brought a complaint before the supreme prosecutor's office against those including the director of the police agency involved in violence committed against unionists of the Daewoo Motor Company, according to Seoul-based Yonhap News.
 They charged that indiscriminate crackdown upon the unionists who were lying in defenseless state could not be construed as a mere excessive exercise of "government" power but it was a grave crime of trampling down human dignity and value.    
 Prior to this, over 50 representatives of various organizations called a press conference in front of the building of the supreme prosecutor's office at which they exposed the group violence by the police and demanded the authorities admit the wrong, thoroughly probe the truth behind it and punish those responsible for it.
